citation.article-title: Numerical and chemical classification of Actinoplanes and some related actinomycetes

p.s: Description of Actinoplanes consettensis sp. nov.
Actinoplanes consettensis (con.sett.en'sis. ML adj. consettensis, belonging to Consett, UK, a town near the site where the organisms were isolated)
Abundant light to yellow-brown substrate mycelium formed on modified Bennett's agar.
Sporangia globose, spores motile and arranged irregularly within sporangia.

Degrades arbutin, casein, DNA, elastin, lecithin, starch and RNA ; utilizes adonitol, L-arabinose, dextrin, D-fructose, D-galactose, D-glucose, D-lactose, D-maltose, Dmannitol, D-mannose, methyl β-D-glucoside, raffinose, L-rhamnose and D-xylose as sole carbon sources but not D-cellobiose, erythritol, meso-inositol, methyl α-D-glucoside, D-ribose, catechol, coumarin, m-, o- or p-hydroxybenzoic acid, syringaldehyde or vanillin.
Nitrate is not reduced and urea is not hydrolysed.
The organism is tolerant to a number of antibiotics and chemical inhibitors (Table 6).
It grows at 4 and 30°C , but not at 37°C.
The wall peptidoglycan contains meso- and hydroxydiaminopimelic acid.
The principal wall sugars are arabinose, galactose, glucose, mannose and xylose.

The organism also contains complex mixtures of straight- and branched-chain fatty acids, with hexadecanoic and 12-methyltetradecanoic acids predominating, tetrahydrogenated menaquinones with nine isoprene units as the predominant isoprenologue, and major amounts of diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylinositol.
Type strain : Actinoplanes consettensis LA97 (IFO 14913; NCIB 20027).
